robustness.tools.breeds_helpers module¶

robustness.tools.breeds_helpers.setup_breeds(info_dir, url='https://github.com/MadryLab/BREEDS-Benchmarks/blob/master/imagenet_class_hierarchy/modified/')¶
class robustness.tools.breeds_helpers.ClassHierarchy(info_dir, root_wnid='n00001740')¶

Bases: object

Class representing a general ImageNet-style hierarchy.

Parameters

info_dir (str) – Path to hierarchy information files. Contains a “class_hierarchy.txt” file with one edge per line, a “node_names.txt” mapping nodes to names, and “class_info.json”.

leaves_reachable(n)¶

Determine the leaves (ImageNet classes) reachable for a give node.

Parameters

n (str) – WordNet ID of node

Returns

List of WordNet IDs of the ImageNet descendants

Return type

leaves (list)

node_name(n)¶

Determine the name of a node.

print_node_info(nodes)¶

Prints basic information (name, number of ImageNet descendants) about a given set of nodes.

Parameters

nodes (list) – List of WordNet IDs for relevant nodes

traverse(nodes, direction='down', depth=100)¶

Find all nodes accessible from a set of given nodes.

Parameters

  • nodes (list) – List of WordNet IDs for relevant nodes

  • direction ("up"/"down") – Traversal direction

  • depth (int) – Maximum depth to traverse (from nodes)

Returns

Set of nodes reachable within the desired depth, in the desired direction.

get_nodes_at_level(L, ancestor=None)¶

Find all superclasses at a specified depth within a subtree of the hierarchy.

Parameters

  • L (int) – Depth in hierarchy (from root node)

  • ancestor (str) – (optional) WordNet ID that can be used to restrict the subtree in which superclasses are found

Returns

Set of superclasses at that depth in

the hierarchy

Return type

nodes (list)

class robustness.tools.breeds_helpers.BreedsDatasetGenerator(info_dir, root_wnid='n00001740')¶

Bases: object

Class for generating datasets from ImageNet superclasses.

split_superclass(superclass_wnid, Nsubclasses, balanced, split_type, rng=numpy.random.RandomState)¶

Split superclass into two disjoint sets of subclasses.

Parameters

  • superclass_wnid (str) – WordNet ID of superclass node

  • Nsubclasses (int) – Number of subclasses per superclass (not used when balanced is True)

  • balanced (bool) – Whether or not the dataset should be balanced over superclasses

  • split_type ("good"/"bad"/"rand") – Whether the subclass partitioning should be more or less adversarial or random

  • rng (RandomState) – Random number generator

Returns

Tuple of lists of subclasses

Return type

class_ranges (tuple)

get_superclasses(level, Nsubclasses=None, split=None, ancestor=None, balanced=True, random_seed=2, verbose=False)¶

Obtain a dataset composed of ImageNet superclasses with a desired set of properties. (Optional) By specifying a split, one can parition the subclasses into two disjoint datasets (with the same superclasses).

Parameters

  • level (int) – Depth in hierarchy (from root node)

  • Nsubclasses (int) – Minimum number of subclasses per superclass

  • balanced (bool) – Whether or not the dataset should be balanced over superclasses

  • split ("good"/"bad"/"rand"/None) – If None, superclasses are not partitioned into two disjoint datasets. If not None, determines whether the subclass partitioning should be more or less adversarial or random

  • rng (RandomState) – Random number generator

Returns

WordNet IDs of superclasses subclass_splits (tuple): Tuple entries correspond to the source

and target domains respectively. A tuple entry is a list, where each element is a list of subclasses to be included in a given superclass in that domain. If split is None, the second tuple element is empty.

label_map (dict): Map from (super)class number to superclass name

Return type

superclasses (list)

robustness.tools.breeds_helpers.print_dataset_info(superclasses, subclass_splits, label_map, label_map_sub)¶

Obtain a dataframe with information about the superclasses/subclasses included in the dataset.

Args: superclasses (list): WordNet IDs of superclasses subclass_splits (tuple): Tuple entries correspond to the source

and target domains respectively. A tuple entry is a list, where each element is a list of subclasses to be included in a given superclass in that domain. If split is None, the second tuple element is empty.

label_map (dict): Map from (super)class number to superclass name label_map_sub (dict): Map from subclass number to subclass name

(equivalent to label map for original dataset)

Returns

Columns contain relevant information

about the datast

Return type

dataDf (pandas DataFrame)

robustness.tools.breeds_helpers.make_entity13(info_dir, split=None)¶

Obtain superclass/subclass information for the ENTITY-13 dataset :param info_dir: Path to ImageNet information files :type info_dir: str :param split: Nature of subclass :type split: “good”/”bad”/”rand”/None

Returns

WordNet IDs of superclasses subclass_splits (tuple): Tuple entries correspond to the source

and target domains respectively. A tuple entry is a list, where each element is a list of subclasses to be included in a given superclass in that domain. If split is None, the second tuple element is empty.

label_map (dict): Map from (super)class number to superclass name

Return type

superclasses (list)

Obtain superclass/subclass information for the NONLIVING-26 dataset. :param info_dir: Path to ImageNet information files :type info_dir: str :param split: Nature of subclass :type split: “good”/”bad”/”rand”/None

and target domains respectively. A tuple entry is a list, where each element is a list of subclasses to be included in a given superclass in that domain. If split is None, the second tuple element is empty.

label_map (dict): Map from (super)class number to superclass name
